title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to coordinate economic sanctions efforts. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to coordinate economic sanctions efforts. The Group includes various offices such as the Office of International Affairs, Economic Policy, Legislative Affairs, Foreign Assets Control, Intelligence and Analysis, Terrorist Financing, and Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The Group conducts contingency planning for the rapid imposition, monitoring, and enforcement of economic sanctions against foreign countries or entities under relevant laws. The contingency planning required for economic sanctions should consider the vulnerability of the foreign country, effectiveness of sanctions, costs to the US economy, unilateral vs. multilateral imposition, and the process for lifting sanctions. The Group will review and identify problems with economic sanctions programs, create a strategy to improve them, and coordinate with the Department of State to develop US economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes will coordinate US economic sanctions policy with various government departments and ensure information sharing. The Group must meet at least once a month and can receive support staff from the Department of the Treasury. They may also consult with policy experts in carrying out their functions. The Group may consult with policy experts from academia, research organizations, the private sector, and other relevant institutions. They are required to submit annual reports to Congress detailing contingency planning, identified problems, and the strategy created under subsection (c)(2)(B). The Group consults with policy experts and submits annual reports to Congress detailing contingency planning, strategy creation, interagency coordination, and sanctions impact assessment. The assessment may use various research methods and include a classified index for congressional briefings. The Group consults with policy experts and submits annual reports to Congress detailing contingency planning, strategy creation, interagency coordination, and sanctions impact assessment. The assessment includes quantitative and qualitative research methods, econometrics, and formal modeling. It assesses the impact of sanctions on foreign and US economies, as well as behavioral changes in response to sanctions. Each report is publicly available on the Department of State's website. The subsection, excluding classified information, will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website and can be updated as economic sanctions programs are changed. Definitions in this section include 'executive agency' and 'United States economic sanctions policy'. A conforming amendment adds the Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group reporting directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group will report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. A clerical amendment adds this group to the table of sections in chapter 3 of the title.
